content.title: Draw a number line graph to display
Square Bracket Notation
content.content: An alternative to using inequality signs is to use square bracket notation.
latex: $[a, b]$ represents the interval $\{x \mid a \leqslant x \leqslant b\}$
$[a, b[$ represents the interval $\{x \mid a \leqslant x < b\}$
$]a, b]$ represents the interval $\{x \mid a < x \leqslant b\}$
$]a, b[$ represents the interval $\{x \mid a < x < b\}$
$\{x \mid 1 \leqslant x < 3 \text{ or } x \geqslant 5\}$ is written as $[1, 3[ \cup [5, \infty[$
content.description: For intervals which extend to infinity, we use the symbol infinity. We always use an 'outwards' bracket for infinity. In square bracket notation, we use the union symbol to replace 'or'.

content.title: Linear inequalities
content.content: Linear inequalities take the same form as linear equations, except they contain an inequality sign instead of an 'equals' sign.

content.title: Rules for Solving Linear Inequalities
content.content: If we interchange the LHS and RHS of an inequality, then we must reverse the inequality sign. $>$ is the reverse of $<$, and $\geqslant$ is the reverse of $\leqslant$.

content.title: Rules for operations on inequalities
rules: If we add or subtract the same number to both sides, the inequality sign is maintained. Example: if $5 > 3$, then $5 + 2 > 3 + 2$
If we multiply or divide both sides by a positive number, the inequality sign is maintained. Example: if $5 > 3$, then $5 \times 2 > 3 \times 2$
If we multiply or divide both sides by a negative number, the inequality sign is reversed. Example: if $5 > 3$, then $5 \times -1 < 3 \times -1$
summary: Interchanging the sides reverses the inequality sign
Multiplying or dividing both sides by a negative number reverses the inequality sign

content.title: Sign diagram components
points: a horizontal line which represents the $x$-axis
positive $(+)$ and negative $(-)$ signs indicating where the graph is above and below the $x$-axis respectively
critical values, which are the graph's $x$-intercepts, or where it is undefined

content.title: Sign diagram example
content.content: Consider the graph of $y = f(x)$ with a vertical asymptote at $x = 2$. The corresponding sign diagram shows negative, positive, negative, and positive regions separated by critical values at 1, 2, and 3.
content.description: We use a solid line to indicate where the function is zero, and a dashed line to indicate where the function is undefined.

content.title: Sign change rules
rules: A sign change occurs about the critical value for single factors such as $(x + 2)$ and $(x - 1)$, indicating cutting of the $x$-axis.
No sign change occurs about the critical value for squared factors such as $(x - 1)^2$, indicating touching of the $x$-axis.

solution.conclusion: The factors are single so the signs alternate
The factors are single so the signs alternate
A squared factor indicates no change of sign about the critical value
Since $(x - 3)$ and $(x + 1)$ are single factors, the signs alternate

content.title: Solving non-linear inequalities
content.content: To solve non-linear inequalities, we use the following procedure:

content.title: Procedure for solving non-linear inequalities
steps: Make the RHS zero by shifting all terms to the LHS.
Draw a sign diagram for the LHS.
Determine the values required from the sign diagram.

questions.label: b
questions.answer: The LHS is always $\geqslant 0$, so the inequality is true for all real $x$.
